awd_titl_txt: NRI: FND: COLLAB: Optimal Design of Robust Compliant Actuators for Ubiquitous Co-Robots
awd_abstract_narration:
Motion of robotic devices is achieved by enabling the movement of its joints by devices called actuators.  This National Robotics Initiative (NRI) project seeks to understand how to design compliant actuators  for human-interactive robots that are energy-efficient and safe across a wide variety of tasks and situations. Unlike rigid actuators, compliant actuators can store and release mechanical energy for greater efficiency and absorb shocks for greater safety, which has made them especially popular in wearable robots (i.e., prostheses and exoskeletons). However, the compliant element of the actuator (e.g., a spring between the motor and the robot joint) must be carefully chosen to achieve these benefits, which has restricted previous implementations to specific use cases. The mathematical framework in this project will enable design of compliant actuators that change their physical properties to guarantee safety and efficiency as interactions vary from gentle to forceful. Compliant actuators that are robust to a wide range of conditions can be used for many applications, allowing mass production at lower cost. The energy efficiency of these actuators will increase the battery range of mobile co-robots and allow the use of smaller, lighter batteries in wearable robots. This work is significant to the ubiquity of compliant actuator technology for safe, energy-efficient interactions between robots and humans in uncertain real-world situations outside the laboratory.

This project will establish a robust convex optimization framework for designing series elastic actuators (SEAs) that globally minimize electrical energy consumption while satisfying actuator/safety constraints. When designing an SEA, a parametric representation of the elastic element (e.g., the stiffness of a linear spring) is typically optimized for a single task (trajectory and load). However, this paradigm has two key limitations: 1) solutions are only optimal within the given space of parameters, and 2) the benefits of the elasticity (i.e., efficiency and compliance) can be entirely lost outside of specific operating conditions. A nonlinear series elastic element can potentially solve these problems by providing different stiffness characteristics at different operating points, but the ideal parameterization of the spring is unknown. A non-parametric, robust optimization framework is therefore needed to develop SEA technology that can achieve a variety of tasks in a variety of situations (customizability) for ubiquitous interaction with humans (scalability). Tools exist to solve convex optimization problems with uncertainty in their parameters, but the design of SEAs is not currently known to be a convex problem. The overall goals of this project are then to 1) understand the convexity of SEA energy consumption as a function of stiffness characteristics, 2) understand how to design nonlinear series elastic elements to achieve maximal efficiency while satisfying constraints, and 3) understand how to design SEAs that are robust to uncertainties.

por.por_cntn:
This project contributed a new methodology to design compliant actuators for human-interactive robots that are energy-efficient and safe across a wide variety of tasks and situations. Unlike rigid actuators, compliant actuators can store and release mechanical energy for greater efficiency and absorb shocks for greater safety, which has made them especially popular in wearable robots (i.e., prostheses and exoskeletons). However, the compliant element of the actuator (e.g., a spring between the motor and the robot joint) must be carefully chosen to achieve these benefits. While most springs have a straight-line relationship between force and displacement (linear stiffness), they don't have to. A nonlinear spring stiffness profile can increase energy efficiency and safety compared to linear designs. Designing the best nonlinear stiffness is challenging because there is an infinite set of nonlinear functions to relate force and displacement. The traditional design of nonlinear springs would solve this challenge by expressing the force and displacement relationship to be within a set of known functions (e.g., polynomials) and optimizing over the function parameters (e.g., coefficient of the polynomials). Unfortunately, those parametric methods cannot guarantee that the solution is the absolute best within all the possible nonlinear functions. We developed a new design framework based on convex optimization that does not require parameterization and guarantees that the resulting nonlinear profile is the absolute best to reduce energy consumption for a given actuation task. Our resulting optimal nonlinear springs resulted in sudden changes in stiffness to exploit the particular properties of a given task. However, when the task deviated from its nominal conditions (e.g., the user of a prosthesis increases walking speed) the nonlinear spring had a negative effect on energy consumption. To solve this challenge, we extended our convex optimization framework to be robust against variations in the parameters of the optimization (e.g., user mass, user speed, and tolerances in spring manufacturing). The resulting design framework is publicly available as source code and enables designers with knowledge of the motion task and motor to find the absolute best series spring that minimizes motor consumption despite bounded uncertainty within the motion tasks.

The investigated optimization framework enables design of compliant actuators that change their stiffness with increased displacement to guarantee safety and efficiency as interactions vary from gentle to forceful. However, this introduces a mechanical design problem: how to implement physical springs to match the non-straight-line force-displacement relationships that come out of the optimization. To this end we have invented a new spring design (see Figure 1) that allows us to approximate a wider variety of relationships. More specifically, we can now implement progressive behaviors where the spring becomes stiffer as it deflects.

Compliant actuators that are robust to a wide range of conditions can be used for many applications, allowing mass production at lower cost. The energy efficiency of these actuators enables the use of smaller, lighter batteries in wearable robots. The novel, lightweight spring designs enable weight saving in wearable robots and lower the barrier to physical realization of nonlinear spring profiles more generally. The optimization code has been made publicly available to lower the barrier to entry for compliant actuator design in the field of human-interactive robots. The investigated optimization framework was extended to the control of variable stiffness actuators, which we demonstrated through an undergraduate senior design project. Further, the extended multi-joint optimization framework enables the design of high-performance actuators for various objectives, which was demonstrated on a humanoid robot. This work is significant to the ubiquity of compliant actuator technology for safe, energy-efficient interactions between robots and humans in uncertain real-world situations outside the laboratory. Between the University of Texas at Dallas, University of Michigan, and University of Denver, this project supported four PhD students, two postdocs, one MS student, and two undergraduate students, including two underrepresented minorities. One trainee secured a tenure-track faculty position, and another was promoted to Research Investigator at the University of Michigan. This project also supported a senior design team involving six undergraduate students and multiple outreach activities to local communities.
